case_vignette: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the ED by his mother because of abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, she noticed he had a fever and looser stools, but both resolved after a few days. One week ago, he began to experience periodic episodes during which he would curl up into a ball, scream, and cry. The episodes lasted a few minutes, and were occasionally followed by vomiting. Between events, he was completely normal. She says the episodes have become more frequent over time, and this morning, she noticed blood in his diaper. In the ED, his vitals are within normal ranges, and his physical exam is normal.
question: After confirming the diagnosis with an abdominal ultrasound, what is the next step in management?

trial_0.multiturn_mcq:
Final Diagnosis: Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)

The next step in management for NEC is supportive care, which includes fluid and electrolyte replacement, pain management, and antibiotics to treat any underlying infection. An abdominal ultrasound may be used to monitor the progression of the disease and to guide further management. An abdominal CT scan may also be used to evaluate the severity of the disease and to guide further management. An air contrast enema may be used to evaluate the integrity of the bowel wall and to guide further management. An abdominal laparotomy may be used in severe cases to remove damaged bowel tissue and to prevent further complications.
